bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Adrian Macia, March 24, 1942

div1.p: Hench implores Macia to preserve Building No. 1 until he has raised enough money to commemorate of the site. Hench assures him that a mutually satisfactory solution can be found for the sale of the land.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Adrian Macia, March 24, 1942
div1.opener:
March 24, 1942
Senor Adrian Macia
Manzana de Gomez 325
Havana, Cuba
My dear Senor Macia:
div1.p:
I am surprised at the return of my check for $150.00 as in your
letter of January 6, you wrote as follows, “In regard to the first question,
I want to inform you that the 150 square yards of land would cost about $150.00.”
I assumed that that was just for the land on which the little house was. You
will remember you warned me that legally speaking the deed which you gave me
last year expires at the end of the year unless we have done something about
it. That was why I was anxious to preserve the little house by purchasing
now the land immediately there under, even though final negotiations cannot
yet be made to purchase the corn field in front of it.

A few weeks ago I had a letter from Dr. Carbonell Ponce which en-
couraged me to believe that he had aroused the interest of the Cuban government
and that they were going to help with the project but I understand that that
matter has been blocked for the time being.

First of all, may I beg of you that you will preserve the little house
while we proceed with our plans in this country to raise the appropriate amount
of money. I am sure that if we are permitted to purchase or receive from you
as a gift the corn field immediately in front of the little shack with its bound-
ary on Calle Luis Valdes Carrero, arrangements could be made to have a satisfactory
entrance to your quarry site, with a road running down to your quarry from Manuel
Virona Suarez. However, this is a detail that can be worked out to mutual satis-
faction, I have no doubt.

The reason I have delayed somewhat in getting our campaign started was
that I know one of the first questions which I will be asked will be, “How much
do they want for the land?” I am afraid there will not be as much chance to
raise the money until I can assure those whom I hope to interest that we actually
can receive a deed to the property, either as a generous gift from you and your
partner, or for a nominal and reasonable sum. As I understand it from your last
letter and from one from Mr. Moran, you continue to be entirely sympathetic to
our venture but do not want to commit yourself utterly until you know we are going
to be able to raise the money. I can see your viewpoint and can sympathize fully
with it; therefore I shall be satisfied with the kind sentiments which you have so
far expressed and tell those whom I plan to interest that so far as I know you are
quite willing to cooperate with us if we here show progress in raising the appro-
priate amount of money for the memorial building. Believe me, Senor Macia, I
appreciate greatly your continued interest in this historical venture.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
